summary.seg: This manuscript, probably copied in the 13th century, contains the Hippiatrica, a compilation of veterinary texts on the care and medical treatment of horses. This collection is believed to have been originally assembled in the 5th or 6th century CE by an anonymous editor who gathered excerpts from seven existing texts. To these other excerpts were added by later editors.

The principal works excerpted, by Eumelos, Apsyrtos, Theonestos, Hierokles, Hippokrates, Pelagonius and Anatolios, themselves date from the 3rd to the 5th centuries CE. Most were originally composed in Greek, but the work of Pelagonius was a translation from Latin. With the exception of that text, these sources have since largely been lost except for the portions excerpted in this compilation. The collection became the standard reference work on its subject and remained so throughout the medieval period.

The compilation exists in multiple recensions, reflecting the adaptation and expansion of the collection by different editors over the centuries. This manuscript belongs to recension D of the text, which is otherwise represented only by one other manuscript, London, British Library, Sloane MS 745, and even between these two there are significant divergences in content and the arrangement of the material. In addition to the original core of the collection, this recension includes excerpts from other authors including Aristotle, Tiberius, Aelian, Julius Africanus, Oribasius, Aetius of Amida, Paul of Amida and Simon of Athens, the earliest known Greek author on horses. The latest components found here are two recipes for medicine attributed to the 10th-century Patriarch of Constantinople Theophylact. (McCabe, p. 38)

This manuscript is a composite assembled from distinct physical components. The first part was copied by a hand probably of the 13th century, on old parchment reused in palimpsest. The undertext is in majuscule script, apparently a text of Christian content. Whereas the creation of palimpsests usually involved rotating the original bifolios through 90° and cutting them in half, here the leaves are either in their original orientation or inverted. Quires are assembled in a very unusual structure for a parchment manuscript, with the hair side of each sheet facing inward towards the centre of the quire and the flesh side facing outwards, whereas normally they would be arranged so that hair faces hair and flesh faces flesh, to avoid an inelegant contrast between the appearance of the inner and outer sides of the skin.

The palimpsest component of the manuscript is followed by another part copied on new parchment, by a different hand. A fresh sequence of quire signatures begins with this second section, indicating that it was not part of the same production project as the first, but was created at some time after the first had been bound. A further indication of a separate context of production is that the beginning of many new textual elements of the compilation has been marked with leather tabs on the edges of the folios, and even where these have been lost, their former presence can be identified by the less discoloured tone of the parchment where it was covered by them. No such tabs or marks are found in the second part. The transition between the two parts occurs in the middle of one of the component texts of the compilation, suggesting that it was not simply an expansion of a manuscript previously considered complete. It may be that the original manuscript had suffered damage, or that the original project had been left incomplete. The chronological relationship between the production of the two parts is unclear, since the hand of the second could date from the later 13th century, potentially placing it in proximity to the first, but could also be of the 14th century.

The third part of the manuscript continues in the same hand and displaying the same sequence of quire signatures, but is written on paper. Again the transition occurs in the midst of a text. It could be that the switch was due to money running short towards the end of the work or to the exhaustion of the immediately available stock of parchment, as this was a more expensive material whose use was becoming unusual in this period.
Components of a former binding have been preserved alongside the manuscript, including scraps from a Latin manuscript, possibly dating from the 12th century, which had been used as binding material.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is paginated [a-d] + I-II (foliation), 1-267, 267x, 268-369 (pagination) + [e-h], in Roman numerals in pencil, and in Arabic numerals in brown ink, recto, upper right and verso, upper left (upper centre for p. 369).

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 24 quires, of which sixteen belong to Part I, seven to Part II and two to Part III: 18-1, 28, 36-1, 44-1, 58, 68-6, 7-98, 108-2, 118, 1212, 13-148, 158-2, 168 | 17-238 | 248, 2510 .

additions.p: There are interlinear and marginal glosses in Greek throughout the manuscript, by a hand probably of the 15th century.

binding.p: Cambridge University Library conservation binding 2021; red full leather cover over wooden boards, with plain pastedowns.

Leather page-marker tabs or portions of them survive on the foredge of pp. 29, 41, 49, 59, 67, 90, 98, 106, 111, 121-122, 151, 186 and 192, and traces of former tabs on pp. 11-14, 39-40, 61-62 and 117-118.

A former binding is preserved separately: 18th-century full leather binding over millboards, with plain pastedowns. There is decorative blind tooling on the edges of the boards. An older label on paper, dating to the 17th or 18th century, is pasted to the left board: Βιβλίον Ἱπποιατρικὸν liber magni pretii quoad partem priorem scriptus accurative plurima continet qua in libro typis excuso (scilicet Basiliae 1537, non comparent). The spine is now detached from the boards, and bears the title De arte veterinaria on a red leather label, as well as the classmark on patches. Two plain paper endleaves are also preserved, as are the sewing cord, pieces of an endband, and slips of parchment and of paper manuscript waste with Latin text and musical notation dated to the 12th century, which had been reused in the bindng for repairs.

history.acquisition: The manuscript had been acquired by Emmanuel College by 1673, when it was collated against a printed copy in which notes citing it were dated. It had apparently been acquired since 1637, as it does not appear in the college library catalogue compiled in that year.

availability.p: Visitors to Emmanuel College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Emmanuel College: Special Collections.

monogr.title: Geoponicorum : sive, De re rustica libri XX

Notices et extraits des manuscrits médicaux grecs, latins et français, des principales bibliothèques de l'Europe. [1], Manuscrits grecs d'Angleterre suivis d'un fragment inédit de Gilles de Corbeil et de scolies inédites sur Hippocrate.
Anecdota cantabrigiensia. Pars I, [De Hippiatricorum codice Cantabrigiensi]
The Western manuscripts in the library of Emmanuel College: a descriptive catalogue

analytic.title: Hand-list of the Greek palimpsests in Cambridge libraries

L'Epitomé de la Collection d'hippiatrie grecque : histoire du texte, édition critique, traduction et notes

monogr.title: A Byzantine encyclopaedia of horse medicine : the sources, compilation, and transmission of the Hippiatrica
Art et science vétérinaire à Byzance : formes et fonctions de l'image hippiatrique

msItem.title: Contents list to Hippiatrica
msItem.incipit: f. i recto (upper text) Περὶ ἑσπιστοῦ καὶ ἐπικυκτίδος: μζʹ Περὶ ὑστριχίδων
msItem.explicit: f. ii recto (upper text) ρθʹ Περὶ σισευασίας ἐγχυματισμῶν

msItem.title: Hippiatrica Cantabrigiensis
msItem.filiation: The text in this manuscript has been designated as belonging to recension D of this collection, which is otherwise represented only by London, British Library, MS Slone 745. This manuscript was used in the preparation of the Teubner edition by Oder and Hoppe, and in Needham's edition of the Geoponica.
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas
msItem.incipit: p. 1 (upper text) Ἡ τοῦ ἵππου ἀρετὴ, ἐκ πρώτης ὑποφαίνεται
msItem.explicit: p. 369 (upper text) καὶ δίδου ἐπὶ ἡμέρας γʹ· ἐκάστω ζῶων, γο γʹ σκ<ευασία δ>ιὰ πικρᾶς
msItem.note: Ed. Eugen Oder and Carl Hoppe, Corpus hippiatricorum graecorum, 2 vols. (Leipzig 1924-1927), vol. 2, pp. 115-252

support.material: pp. 1-222 Parchment (FHFHFHFHHFHFHFHF), of variable thickness and quite poor quality.

collation.p: This part consists of 15 quires, of which one is a binion, one a ternion, one of twelve folios and the rest are quaternia. This collation differs from those of previous publications by treating the ambiguous case of pp. 27-42 as two quires rather than one; see note to Quire 3.

list.item: Quire 18-1 ff. I-II, pp. 1-10 The third folio has been lost, with loss of text

Quire 36-1 pp. 27-36 One of the last three folios has been cancelled, without loss of text; these five folios and the following three are treated by both sets of signatures as a single quire, numbered 3; however, physically they form two distinct entities, the first of five folios, with the current stitching following the third folio, arranged FHFHFHHFHF, the second of three folios with the stitching following the first folio, arranged FHHFHF; the disposition thus accords with treating them as forming two distinct quires, given the pattern normally found in this manuscript
Quire 44-1 pp. 37-42 The first or second folio has been cancelled, without loss of text; see note to previous quire
Quire 68-6 pp. 59-62 All but two folios have been lost, with loss of text; the first folio is one of those that remain.
Quire 108-2 pp. 111-122 The fourth and fifth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 158-2 pp. 195-206 The fourth and fifth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in brown ink, on the last folio of each quire, verso, lower right or lower centre (to Quire 12) and in bright red ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre (from Quire 13). The number 9 (θʹ) was erroneously marked in brown ink on Quire 6 and later struck through and replaced with the correct number 6 (ϛʹ) in bright red ink. They survive on Quires 1-2, 4-5, 7-9, 11-16, treating what have been designated in this description as Quires 3 and 4 as a single quire, numbered 3 (αʹ-δʹ, ϛʹ-ηʹ, ιʹ-ιεʹ).

There are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in black ink, in a late medieval or early modern style on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They survive on Quires 2, 4-16, treating what have been designated in this description as Quires 3 and 4 as a single quire, numbered 3 (2-15).

There is a second sequence of quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in black ink, in a more modern style on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, giving the same numbers as the first. They survive on Quires 7-8 (6-7).

supportDesc.condition: There are small tears to the edges of some folios, which have been repaired with paper. There is some creasing, water staining and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout:
pp. 1-222 (upper text) A single column of 20-24 lines.
183-194 135
Pricking occasionally survives in the outer margin, but most has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 4, type possibly Leroy 40C1s, but this is unclear as the folios appear to have been significantly cut down for their reuse here in palimpsest. Text stands on the lines.

handNote.p: pp. 1-222 (upper text) were copied by Hand A in mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points and full stop.
Headings were copied in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the 13th century, as suggested by the style of script. James dates it to the 12th century, Tchernetska to the 13th; the latter also suggests that it resembles the scripts of this period from the region of Otranto, indicating that it may have been produced in southern Italy.

support.material: pp. 1-222 Parchment (FHFHFHFHHFHFHFHF), of variable thickness and quite poor quality.

collation.p: This part consists of 15 quires, of which one is a binion, one a ternion, one of twelve folios and the rest are quaternia. This collation differs from those of previous publications by treating the ambiguous case of pp. 27-42 as two quires rather than one; see note to Quire 3.

list.item: Quire 18-1 ff. I-II, pp. 1-10 The third folio has been lost, with loss of text

Quire 36-1 pp. 27-36 One of the last three folios has been cancelled, without loss of text; these five folios and the following three are treated by both sets of signatures as a single quire, numbered 3; however, physically they form two distinct entities, the first of five folios, with the current stitching following the third folio, arranged FHFHFHHFHF, the second of three folios with the stitching following the first folio, arranged FHHFHF; the disposition thus accords with treating them as forming two distinct quires, given the pattern normally found in this manuscript
Quire 44-1 pp. 37-42 The first or second folio has been cancelled, without loss of text; see note to previous quire
Quire 68-6 pp. 59-62 All but two folios have been lost, with loss of text; the first folio is one of those that remain.
Quire 108-2 pp. 111-122 The fourth and fifth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 158-2 pp. 195-206 The fourth and fifth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in brown ink, on the last folio of each quire, verso, lower right or lower centre (to Quire 12) and in bright red ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre (from Quire 13). The number 9 (θʹ) was erroneously marked in brown ink on Quire 6 and later struck through and replaced with the correct number 6 (ϛʹ) in bright red ink. They survive on Quires 1-2, 4-5, 7-9, 11-16, treating what have been designated in this description as Quires 3 and 4 as a single quire, numbered 3 (αʹ-δʹ, ϛʹ-ηʹ, ιʹ-ιεʹ).

There are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in black ink, in a late medieval or early modern style on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They survive on Quires 2, 4-16, treating what have been designated in this description as Quires 3 and 4 as a single quire, numbered 3 (2-15).

There is a second sequence of quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in black ink, in a more modern style on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, giving the same numbers as the first. They survive on Quires 7-8 (6-7).

supportDesc.condition: There are small tears to the edges of some folios, which have been repaired with paper. There is some creasing, water staining and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout:
pp. 1-222 (lower text) A single column of 20-24 lines, sometimes in the same orientation as the upper text, sometimes rotated 180°. 183-194 135
Pricking occasionally survives in the outer margin, but most has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 4, type possibly Leroy 40C1s, but this is unclear as the folios appear to have been significantly cut down for their reuse here in palimpsest. Text stands on the lines.

handNote.p: pp. 1-222 (lower text) were copied by Hand B in slanted ogival majuscule script, in brown ink.

history.origin: The lower text of the palimpsest folios was probably copied in the 8th century, as suggested by the style of script.

msItem.title: Hippiatrica Cantabrigiensis (continued)
msItem.filiation: The text in this manuscript has been designated as belonging to recension D of this collection, which is otherwise represented only by London, British Library, MS Slone 745. This manuscript was used in the preparation of the Teubner edition by Oder and Hoppe, and in Needham's edition of the Geoponica.
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas
msItem.incipit: p. 1 (upper text) Ἡ τοῦ ἵππου ἀρετὴ, ἐκ πρώτης ὑποφαίνεται
msItem.explicit: p. 369 (upper text) καὶ δίδου ἐπὶ ἡμέρας γʹ· ἐκάστω ζῶων, γο γʹ σκ<ευασία δ>ιὰ πικρᾶς
msItem.note: Ed. Eugen Oder and Carl Hoppe, Corpus hippiatricorum graecorum, 2 vols. (Leipzig 1924-1927), vol. 2, pp. 115-252

support.material: pp. 223-333 Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and quality.

collation.p: This part consists of seven quires, all quaternia.
collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in pale red ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, beginning afresh from the number 1 and continuing into Part III. They survive on all quires of this part (αʹ-ζʹ).

There are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, belonging to the sequence running throughout the manuscript. Their numbering differs from that of this description due to this sequence's treatment of pp. 27-42 as a single quire. They survive on all quires of this part (16-22).

supportDesc.condition: There are areas of dirt, slight cockling and occasional creasing.

layoutDesc.layout:
pp. 223-333 A single column of 22-24 lines. 172-187 180-190
Pricking survives in all three margins, but has often been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 00C1. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: pp. 223-369 were copied by Hand C in mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.
Headings were copied in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.
A cross has been marked on f. 223 by making small indentations in the folio.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the later 13th or 14th century, as suggested by the style of script.

msItem.title: Hippiatrica Cantabrigiensis (continued)
msItem.filiation: The text in this manuscript has been designated as belonging to recension D of this collection, which is otherwise represented only by London, British Library, MS Slone 745. This manuscript was used in the preparation of the Teubner edition by Oder and Hoppe, and in Needham's edition of the Geoponica.
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas
msItem.incipit: p. 1 (upper text) Ἡ τοῦ ἵππου ἀρετὴ, ἐκ πρώτης ὑποφαίνεται
msItem.explicit: p. 369 (upper text) καὶ δίδου ἐπὶ ἡμέρας γʹ· ἐκάστω ζῶων, γο γʹ σκ<ευασία δ>ιὰ πικρᾶς
msItem.note: Ed. Eugen Oder and Carl Hoppe, Corpus hippiatricorum graecorum, 2 vols. (Leipzig 1924-1927), vol. 2, pp. 115-252

collation.p: This part consists of two quires, of which one is a quaternion and the other a quinion.
collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in pale red ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, continuing the sequence beginning with Part II. One survives on Quire 23 (ηʹ).

There are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in brown ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, belonging to the sequence running throughout the manuscript. They survive on both quires of this part, their numbering differing from that of this description due to this sequence's treatment of pp. 27-42 as a single quire (23-24).

supportDesc.condition: pp. 334-369 There is significant pest damage and losses from the edges of some folios, increasing towards the end of the manuscript. This damage has been repaired with Japanese paper. The paper has become soft. There is water staining and some areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout: pp. 334-369 A single column of 22-24 lines. 190-200 135

handNote.p: pp. 223-369 were copied by Hand C in mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.
Headings were copied in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the later 13th or 14th century, as suggested by the style of script.
